response.answer_text: First write the associative property as (x+y)+z = x+(y+z). This way you won’t confuse the a,b, c and d of your equation with the a, b and c of the associative property. Now we just need to figure out the appropriate substitution. Looking at the left-hand side of the equation x=a, y=b and z=(c+d) might be a good thing to try. (a+b) + (c+d) = (x + y) + z - substitution = x + (y + z) - by associativity = a + (b + (c+d)) - substitution We got it! Suppose we had tried x=(a+b), y=c and z=d, what would we get? (a+b) + (c+d) = x + (y + z) = substitution = (x + y) + z - by associativity = ((a + b) + c) + d - substitution So that’s backwards. If you happened to pick this substitution on your first try then don’t worry. Just pick new values and try again. Note that by combining the results we get… a + (b + (c+d)) = (a + b) + (c + d) = ((a + b) + c) + d So we’ve directly proved equality of three of the five forms. The other two are (a + (b + c)) + d a + ((b + c) + d) They’re also equivalent but I’ll leave the proof as an exercise. (And if you’re interested in how we know there’s only five check out the Catalin Numbers.) These proofs are a bit formal. Once you’ve worked through a few example like this it’s usually enough to say that any change in parentheses will result in the same value. Just be careful if you’re mixing operations. (a + b) * c isn’t the same as a + (b * c).
Addition is associative, i.e. (a+b)+c = a+(b+c). You need to apply this law. I won’t do it for you, but I’ll give you a hint: Treat c+d as one thing.
